<research_summary>
<gene_function>
Psb28 is an accessory protein involved in the assembly and stability of Photosystem II (PSII) in cyanobacteria. It primarily binds to the CP43-less PSII assembly intermediate (RC47) on the cytoplasmic surface, facilitating its conversion into functional PSII complexes[1][2][3]. The protein interacts structurally with CP47 and influences chlorophyll biosynthesis, particularly at the cyclization step of protochlorophyllide formation[1]. In Chlamydomonas, Psb28 is essential for proper PSII assembly, with mutants showing severe impairment in PSII supercomplex formation and accumulation of early assembly intermediates[4].

</gene_function>

<physiological_impact>
Deletion of Psb28 reduces autotrophic growth rates and alters cellular photosystem stoichiometry. Mutants exhibit decreased PSI content and accelerated D1 protein turnover in PSII[1]. Thylakoid membrane organization is disrupted, with mutants showing predominantly monolayer structures and distorted chloroplast morphology[4]. Chlorophyll biosynthesis is impaired at the Mg-protoporphyrin IX methylester cyclization step, leading to protoporphyrin IX accumulation and reduced protochlorophyllide levels[1].

</physiological_impact>

<stress_response>
Psb28 is critical for stress resilience, particularly under high-light and high-temperature conditions. It protects the RC47 intermediate from damage during PSII repair cycles, with mutants showing impaired PSII recovery after photodamage[2][3]. This protective role becomes essential under conditions of increased PSII turnover, where absence of Psb28 significantly delays reassembly of functional PSII[3][4].

</stress_response>
